byline.contributor: Michael J. de la Merced contributed reporting from San Francisco.

abstract: Japanese officials say country will not be founding member of new Chinese-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, but instead will support United States, which has asked allies to not join bank.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said it was important for strategic reasons that Japan back the United States, which has urged allies not to join the bank.

headline.main: Japan, Sticking With U.S., Says It Won’t Join China-Led Bank
headline.print_headline: Japan Says It Won’t Join New Bank Led by China

snippet: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said it was important for strategic reasons that Japan back the United States, which has urged allies not to join the bank.
